docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 1 REQUESTS TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS OR CALL WITNESSES [ss 166–169]

heading.title: DIVISION 1 REQUESTS TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS OR CALL WITNESSES [ss 166–169]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 1 REQUESTS TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS OR CALL WITNESSES [ss 166–169]

leg:heading.title: REQUESTS TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS OR CALL WITNESSES [ss 166–169]

p.text: Section 182 of the Commonwealth Act gives Division 1 of Part 4.6 of the Commonwealth Act a wider application in relation to Commonwealth records and certain Commonwealth records.
[Note am Act No 53 of 2000 Sch 1]
In this Division:
means a request that a party (“the requesting party”) makes to another party to do one or more of the following:
to produce to the requesting party the whole or a part of a specified document or thing,
to permit the requesting party, adequately and in an appropriate way, to examine, test or copy the whole or a part of a specified document or thing,
to call as a witness a specified person believed to be concerned in the production or maintenance of a specified document or thing,
to call as a witness a specified person in whose possession or under whose control a specified document or thing is believed to be or to have been at any time,

in relation to a document of the kind referred to in paragraph (b) or (c) of the definition of “document” in the Dictionary — to permit the requesting party, adequately and in an appropriate way, to examine and test the document and the way in which it was produced and has been kept,
in relation to evidence of a previous representation — to call as a witness the person who made the previous representation,

in relation to evidence that a person has been convicted of an offence, being evidence to which section 92(2) applies — to call as a witness a person who gave evidence in the proceeding in which the person was so convicted.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,585] s 167 Requests may be made about certain matters

leg:heading.title: Requests may be made about certain matters

p.text: A party may make a reasonable request to another party for the purpose of determining a question that relates to:
a previous representation, or
evidence of a conviction of a person for an offence, or
the authenticity, identity or admissibility of a document or thing.
See Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 6 of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .
ALRC 38 para 241(c)
Legislation cited in [51,585.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

A request can only be made for the purpose of determining a question that relates to one of the matters specifically stated in the section. Whether a question “relates to” any particular subject matter is a matter of impression to be gathered from the whole of the context and circumstances: Australian Securities Commission v Bank Leumi Le-Israel (Switzerland) (1996) 69 FCR 531 at 547; 139 ALR 527; 14 ACLC 1576; BC9604332 . In the context of ss 166–169 of the Evidence Act the phrase "relates to" involves a nexus of a broad nature and does not require a direct and immediate connection. O'Grady v Northern Queensland Co Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 356 at 365; 92 ALR 213; BC9002928 ; Nordland Paper AG v Anti-Dumping Authority (1999) 93 FCR 454 at 461; 161 ALR 120 at 126; [1999] FCA 10; BC9900019 ; Jennings Constructions Pty Ltd v Workers' Rehabilitation & Compensation Corp (1998) 71 SASR 465 at 480–1; 197 LSJS 448; BC9802969 . The concepts of “authenticity, identity or admissibility” referred to in s 167(c) are not truly disjunctive. There is a sense in which the apparent authenticity and identity of a particular document must be established in order to demonstrate its relevance and admissibility: National Australia Bank Ltd v Rusu (1999) 47 NSWLR 309 at [17]–[19]; [1999] NSWSC 539; BC9902958 ; Daw v Toyworld (NSW) Pty Ltd (2001) 21 NSWCCR 389; [2001] NSWCA 25; BC200100409 at [46] ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) v Rich (2005) 216 ALR 320 at [93] [121]; 191 FLR 385; [2005] NSWSC 417; BC200502844 . The disjunctive use of the three concepts suggests that questions potentially within the wide “relates to” permission conferred by s 167 , are not restricted to the formal identity or origin of a document. They may include questions relating to the accuracy and reality of the events it purports to record: Trimcoll Pty Ltd v Deputy Commissioner of Taxation [2007] NSWCA 307; BC200709267 at [30]–[33] and [64]–[65] (questions designed to establish that the documents recorded sham transactions); see also NM Rural Enterprises Pty Ltd v Rimanui Farms Ltd [2010] NSWSC 1036; BC201006710 ; R (Cth) v Milne (No 1) (2010) 260 FLR 166; [2010] NSWSC 932; BC201010733 . If the request is not complied with, and there is no reasonable cause for the non-compliance, the court may make orders under s 169 of the Act. (The matters that may constitute reasonable cause for non-compliance are set out in s 169(4) of the Act.) Those orders may include a direction requiring a party to comply with the request, or an order preventing the admission of the evidence to which the request relates.
Legislation cited in [51,585.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 167, s 169.

If the request is not reasonable, that fact will jeopardise the ability of the requesting party to make a successful application under s 169 of the Act if the request is not complied with. Although the section does not specify any criteria against which the question of reasonableness should be determined, they must necessarily include the issues raised in the proceedings and the degree of apparent relevance the proposed questions have to those issues. In determining what degree of apparent relevance will suffice to justify a conclusion that the request is reasonable, it is appropriate to take into account that the request will often be made at an early stage of the proceedings before the precise nature and extent of the factual matters in issue have been fully determined. In order to render a request “reasonable” for the purposes of s 167 , it is sufficient if there are previous representations, documents or things that are likely to be relied on as material evidence in the course of the trial: Trimcoll Pty Ltd v Deputy Commissioner of Taxation [2007] NSWCA 307; BC200709267 at [61] .

level.toc-caption: [51,585.20] Notice requirements imposed by the Act

p.text: Legislation cited in [51,585.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 4.

heading.title: Notice requirements imposed by the Act

p.text: The present section appears to assume that the requesting party will have received prior notice from the other party about the intended use of the document, thing, representation or conviction. There are various sections of the Act that impose notice requirements as a precondition of the admissibility of particular types of evidence. Those provisions include the following:
s 67 which relates to reliance on first hand hearsay
s 73 which relates to reputation evidence in criminal proceedings
s 97 which relates to tendency evidence
s 98 which relates to coincidence evidence
s 177 which relates to reliance upon a certificate of expert evidence
In addition, other provisions of the Act require service of copies of documents. These include:
s 33 which relates to police statements
s 49 which relates to foreign documents
s 50 which relates to summaries of documents
s 67 (read with Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 4 ) which relates to first hand hearsay)
s 173 which relates to affidavits establishing the admissibility of first hand hearsay
Legislation cited in [51,585.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 166, 167.

A careful reading of ss 166 and 167 reveals that it will often be the requesting party who intends to rely upon the matter that is the subject of the request. In those circumstances, the request will not have been prompted by any notice from the opposing party. The section does not impose any time limit for the making of any such "unprompted" requests. However, the time when they are made will obviously be a consideration both in relation to whether it is a reasonable request and as to whether, if it is not complied with, the other party had reasonable cause for non-compliance.
Legislation cited in [51,585.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Part 10.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 160, s 181.

The Act does not contain any specific procedure for the service of notices or requests. Presumably documents may be served in accordance with the Rules of court: see Part 10 and the notes thereto. Alternatively, the provisions of the Act relating to delivery of postal articles may provide a means of proving service: see s 160 . Section 181 contemplates that proof of the giving of the notice may be proved by affidavit. The terms of the section appear to assume that postal delivery is a sufficient means of service of notices.
Legislation cited in [51,585.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 168.

Requests may be made even where the tendering party is not required to give prior notice. In such a case, the entitlement to make a request under this Division does not prevent the documents being admitted into evidence before the expiry of the time limits in s 168 of the Evidence Act 1995: Australian Petroleum Pty Ltd v Parnell Transport Industries Pty Ltd (1998) 88 FCR 537; 159 ALR 477 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,590] s 168 Time limits for making certain requests

leg:heading.title: Time limits for making certain requests

p.text: If a party has given to another party written notice of its intention to adduce evidence of a previous representation, the other party may only make a request to the party relating to the representation if the request is made within 21 days after the notice was given.

Despite subsection (1) , the court may give the other party leave to make a request relating to the representation after the end of that 21 day period if it is satisfied that there is a good reason to do so.

If a party has given to another party written notice of its intention to adduce evidence of a person's conviction of an offence in order to prove a fact in issue, the other party may only make a request relating to evidence of the conviction if the request is made within 21 days after the notice is given.

Despite subsection (3) , the court may give the other party leave to make a request relating to evidence of the conviction after the end of that 21 day period if it is satisfied that there is good reason to do so.

If a party has served on another party a copy of a document that it intends to tender in evidence, the other party may only make a request relating to the document if the request is made within 21 days after service of the copy.

If the copy of the document served under subsection (5) is accompanied by, or has endorsed on it, a notice stating that the document is to be tendered to prove the contents of another document, the other party may only make a request relating to the other document if the request is made within 21 days after service of the copy.

Despite subsections (5) and (6) , the court may give the other party leave to make a request relating to the document, or other document, after the end of the 21 day period if it is satisfied that there is good reason to do so.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,595] s 169 Failure or refusal to comply with requests

leg:heading.title: Failure or refusal to comply with requests

p.text: If the party has, without reasonable cause, failed or refused to comply with a request, the court may, on application, make one or more of the following orders:
an order directing the party to comply with the request,
an order that the party produce a specified document or thing, or call as a witness a specified person, as mentioned in section 166 ,
an order that the evidence in relation to which the request was made is not to be admitted in evidence,
such order with respect to adjournment or costs as is just.

If the party had, within a reasonable time after receiving the request, informed the other party that it refuses to comply with the request, any application under subsection (1) by the other party must be made within a reasonable time after being so informed.

The court may, on application, direct that evidence in relation to which a request was made is not to be admitted in evidence if an order made by it under subsection (1)(a) or (b) is not complied with.
Without limiting the circumstances that may constitute reasonable cause for a party to fail to comply with a request, it is reasonable cause to fail to comply with a request if:
the document or thing to be produced is not available to the party, or
the existence and contents of the document are not in issue in the proceeding in which evidence of the document is proposed to be adduced, or
the person to be called as a witness is not available.
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account in relation to the exercise of a power under subsection (1) , it is to take into account:
the importance in the proceeding of the evidence in relation to which the request was made, and
whether there is likely to be a dispute about the matter to which the evidence relates, and
whether there is a reasonable doubt as to the authenticity or accuracy of the evidence that is, or the document the contents of which are, sought to be proved, and
whether there is a reasonable doubt as to the authenticity of the document or thing that is sought to be tendered, and
if the request relates to evidence of a previous representation — whether there is a reasonable doubt as to the accuracy of the representation or of the evidence on which it was based, and

in the case of a request referred to in paragraph (g) of the definition of "request" in section 166 — whether another person is available to give evidence about the conviction or the facts that were in issue in the proceeding in which the conviction was obtained, and
whether compliance with the request would involve undue expense or delay or would not be reasonably practicable, and
the nature of the proceeding.
Clause 5 of Part 2 of the Dictionary is about the availability of documents and things, and clause 4 of Part 2 of the Dictionary is about the availability of persons.
Subsections 168(1) , (3) , (5) and (6) are notification provisions for the purposes of Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 3(1) of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .
Legislation cited in [51,595.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 166.
The classes or categories of circumstances that may constitute reasonable cause for a party not to comply with a request under s 166 are not limited or closed and will include:
the known unavailability of the person who is the subject of the request to be called as a witness;
those cases where there is no cogent reason for the request, such as where the existence and contents of the document are not in issue in the proceedings in question;
Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v Trimcoll Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1324; BC200511049 .
